#Text=Wawrzyniec Grzymała Goślicki

#Text=Wawrzyniec Grzymała Goślicki ( Latin : Laurentius Grimaldius Goslicius ; between 1530 and 1540 – 31 October 1607 ) was a Polish nobleman , Bishop of Poznań ( 1601 – 1607 ) , political thinker and philosopher best known for his book De optimo senatore ( 1568 ) .
#Text=Biography
#Text=Born near Płock , after studying at Kraków 's Jagiellonian University and at Padua and Bologna , [ 1 ]
#Text=he entered the Roman Catholic Church .

#Text=In 1569 he also joined the Polish royal chancery and as a secretary served two kings , Sigismund II Augustus and Stefan Batory , and was successively appointed bishop of Kamieniec Podolski ( 1586 ) , Chełm ( 1590 ) , Przemyśl ( 1591 ) , and Poznań ( 1601 ) . [ 1 ] [ 2 ]
#Text=Goślicki was a man of affairs , highly esteemed by contemporaries , and frequently engaged in active politics .
#Text=He was also a staunch advocate of religious tolerance in Poland .
#Text=It was due to his influence and to a letter that he wrote to the Pope against the Jesuits that they were prevented from establishing schools at Kraków during his reign .
#Text=He was the only prelate who , in 1587 , acceded to the Warsaw Confederation .

#Text=Goślicki 's Latin book De optimo senatore ( published during his stay in Italy in Venice , 1568 [ 2 ] ) and dedicated to King Zygmunt August , subsequently appeared in four English translations : as The Counsellor ( considered inaccurate ) in 1598 , A commonwealth of good counsaile
#Text=in 1607 , The Accomplished Senator ... Done into English ... By Mr. Oldisworth in 1733 , and most recently as The Accomplished Senator in K. Thompson 's translation in 1992 .

#Text=The book proved immensely important in Britain among forces opposed to the Tudor monarchy ; it was widely quoted and cited in opposition pamphlets and leaflets during the period leading up to the British Civil Wars of the 1640s . [ 3 ]
#Text=In this book Goślicki shows the ideal statesman who is well versed in the humanities as well as in economy , politics , and law .
#Text=He argued that law is above the ruler , who must respect it , and that it is illegitimate to rule over a people against its will .
#Text=He equated godliness with reason , and reason with law . [ 1 ]
#Text=Many of the book 's ideas comprised the foundations of Polish Nobles ' Democracy ( 1505 – 1795 ) and were based on 14th-century writings by Stanisław of Skarbimierz .
#Text=The book was not translated into Polish for 400 years . [ 1 ]
#Text=The book was influential abroad , exporting the ideas of Poland 's Golden Freedom and democratic system .
#Text=It was a political and social classic , widely read and long popular in England after its 1598 translation ; [ 4 ]
#Text=read by Elizabeth I of England , it was also known by Shakespeare , who used his depiction of an incompetent senator as a model for Polonius in Hamlet . [ 1 ]
#Text=Its ideas might be seen in the turmoil that gripped England around the times of Glorious Revolution . [ 1 ]
#Text=Goślicki 's ideas were perhaps suggestive for future national constitutions .

#Text=Goślicki never wrote that " all men are created equal , " but did say , " Sometimes a people , justly provoked and irritated , by the Tyranny and Usurpations of their Kings , take upon themselves the undoubted Right of vindicating their own liberties . "

#Text=The book was allegedly read by Robert Bellarmine , Algernon Sydney and Thomas Jefferson ( who had it in his library [ 5 ] ) , but there is no evidence of a direct link with Jefferson 's Declaration of Independence . [ 1 ]
#Text=Goślicki argued that distinguished senators were more useful to a state than the king or the common people :
#Text=For the king , being alone , cannot see everything and it often happens that either he yields to desires or his emotions disturb his ability of discretion .

#Text=Also an ignorant crowd without a thought and head ( as a proverb says ) cannot by any means possess such prudence , while the senate , composed of men distinguished by virtue , prudence , and glory of accomplished deeds is capable from its middle position , as if from an observation point , of caring for the common weal of the state , perceiving those matters which are beneficial , and freeing it from disturbances , rebellions , and dangers . [ 2 ]
#Text=He was an influence in the framing the Polish Constitution of 3 May 1791 , which historian Norman Davies calls " the first constitution of its kind in Europe " . [ 6 ]
